article:
J. Robert Oppenheimer

J. Robert Oppenheimer was a renowned American theoretical physicist and director of the Manhattan Project, the secret research and development project that produced the atomic bomb during World War II. Known as the "father of the atomic bomb," Oppenheimer was a complex figure whose life was marked by both brilliance and turmoil. This article explores his early life, career, and legacy, providing a comprehensive overview of his life and work.

# Early life

## Childhood and education

Julius Robert Oppenheimer was born on April 22, 1904, in New York City, to Ella and Julius Oppenheimer, a textile importer. He was the first of two children, with his brother Frank being born two years later. The Oppenheimer family was of Jewish descent, but they did not practice their faith strictly. Robert's early life was marked by a comfortable upbringing, with his family residing in a luxurious apartment on the Upper West Side.

Oppenheimer was a curious child, often taking things apart and reassembling them. He developed an interest in science and mathematics at an early age, encouraged by his parents. He attended the Ethical Culture School, a progressive private school in New York City, where he excelled academically. In 1921, he entered Harvard University, where he studied chemistry, physics, and mathematics.

## Studies in Europe

After graduating from Harvard in 1925, Oppenheimer traveled to Europe to pursue further studies. He enrolled at the University of Cambridge, where he worked under the supervision of J.J. Thomson, a renowned physicist. However, he soon became dissatisfied with the Cambridge environment and moved to the University of GÃ¶ttingen in Germany, where he studied under Max Born, a prominent physicist.

GÃ¶ttingen was a hub of intellectual activity, and Oppenheimer was exposed to some of the most influential minds in physics, including Werner Heisenberg and Niels Bohr. He earned his Ph.D. in 1927 and returned to the United States, where he took up a position as a lecturer at the University of California, Berkeley.

# Early career

## Teaching

Oppenheimer's early career was marked by a series of teaching positions at various universities. He taught at the University of California, Berkeley, the California Institute of Technology, and Princeton University. He was known for his charismatic teaching style and his ability to inspire his students.

## Scientific work

During the 1920s and 1930s, Oppenheimer made significant contributions to the field of theoretical physics. He worked on a range of topics, including quantum mechanics, relativity, and nuclear physics. His work on the Oppenheimer-Phillips process, a mechanism for nuclear fusion, was particularly notable.

# Private and political life

## Politics

Oppenheimer was a liberal and a supporter of left-wing causes. He was a member of the American Communist Party and was involved in various progressive organizations. However, his involvement with the Communist Party was limited, and he never held a high-ranking position.

## Relationships and children

Oppenheimer married Katherine "Kitty" Posen in 1940. Kitty was a former Communist Party member and had been involved in various left-wing activities. The couple had two children, Toni and Peter.

## Mysticism

Oppenheimer was fascinated by Eastern mysticism and philosophy. He was particularly drawn to the Bhagavad Gita, an ancient Hindu text. He saw parallels between the principles of quantum mechanics and the concepts of Eastern mysticism, and he often incorporated elements of mysticism into his lectures and writings.

# Manhattan Project

## Los Alamos

In 1942, Oppenheimer was appointed director of the Manhattan Project, a secret research and development project aimed at producing an atomic bomb. He established a research laboratory at Los Alamos, New Mexico, where a team of scientists and engineers worked on the development of the bomb.

## Bomb design

Oppenheimer played a crucial role in the design of the atomic bomb. He worked closely with other scientists, including Enrico Fermi and Ernest Lawrence, to develop a workable design. The team faced numerous challenges, including the development of a suitable nuclear reactor and the creation of a mechanism for detonating the bomb.

## Trinity

On July 16, 1945, the Manhattan Project team conducted the Trinity test, the first nuclear test in history. Oppenheimer was present at the test, which was held in the desert near Alamogordo, New Mexico. The test was a success, and it marked a major milestone in the development of the atomic bomb.

# Postwar activities

## Institute for Advanced Study

After the war, Oppenheimer returned to academia and took up a position as the director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton University. He remained in this position until 1966, when he retired.

## Atomic Energy Commission

Oppenheimer was a member of the Atomic Energy Commission (AEC), a regulatory body established to oversee the development and use of nuclear energy. He played a key role in shaping the commission's policies and was a vocal advocate for international cooperation on nuclear issues.

## Panels and study groups

Oppenheimer was a member of various panels and study groups, including the General Advisory Committee of the AEC and the National Academy of Sciences. He played a key role in advising the government on scientific and technical matters.

## Security hearing

In 1954, Oppenheimer was the subject of a security hearing, which was convened to investigate his loyalty and suitability for access to classified information. The hearing was sparked by Oppenheimer's opposition to the development of the hydrogen bomb and his association with left-wing individuals. The hearing was a major controversy, and it marked the beginning of the end of Oppenheimer's involvement in government affairs.

# Final years

## Enrico Fermi Award

In 1963, Oppenheimer was awarded the Enrico Fermi Award, a prestigious honor bestowed by the AEC. The award recognized his contributions to the development of nuclear energy and his leadership of the Manhattan Project.

# Death

J. Robert Oppenheimer died on February 18, 1967, at the age of 62, due to complications from throat cancer.

# Legacy

Oppenheimer's legacy is complex and multifaceted. He is remembered as a brilliant physicist and a charismatic leader, who played a crucial role in the development of the atomic bomb. He is also remembered as a complex and conflicted individual, who struggled with the moral implications of his work.

# Publications

Oppenheimer was a prolific writer and published numerous papers and articles on scientific and technical topics. He also wrote several books, including "The Flying Trapeze: Three Crises for Physicists" and "The Open Mind".

article:
Wangaratta Football Club

The Wangaratta Football Club, also known as the Wangaratta Magpies, is a country football club based in Wangaratta, Victoria, Australia. The club was founded in 1880 and has a rich history of competition in various leagues, including the Ovens and Murray Football League. The Magpies have a strong following in the local community and have produced several notable footballers who have gone on to play in the Victorian Football League (VFL) and Australian Football League (AFL).

# Club History

The Wangaratta Football Club was established in 1880, making it one of the oldest football clubs in Victoria. The club's early years were marked by competition in local leagues, including the Wangaratta District Football Association. In 1893, the club joined the Ovens and Murray Football Association, which later became the Ovens and Murray Football League.

Throughout its history, the Wangaratta Football Club has experienced periods of success and struggle. The club has won several premierships, including four in the Ovens and Murray Football League. The Magpies have also produced several notable footballers who have gone on to play in the VFL and AFL.

2023 Cricket World Cup

The 2023 ICC Cricket World Cup is scheduled to be the 13th edition of the Cricket World Cup, a quadrennial international cricket tournament contested by national teams from the International Cricket Council (ICC). The tournament is set to take place in India from October to November 2023, featuring 10 teams and 48 matches.

# Background

The 2023 ICC Cricket World Cup was awarded to India by the ICC in June 2013, as part of a package of major ICC events to be held in the country. The tournament was originally scheduled to take place in February-April 2023, but was later rescheduled to October-November 2023 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The 2023 World Cup will be the first ICC event to be held in India since the 2016 ICC World Twenty20.

# Qualification

The qualification process for the 2023 ICC Cricket World Cup involved the top 8 teams from the ICC ODI rankings as of March 2022, plus the top 2 teams from the ICC Cricket World Cup Super League. The Super League was a 2-year competition featuring the 13 teams that missed out on automatic qualification, with the top 2 teams earning a spot in the World Cup.

article:
Finlandâ€“NATO relations
======================

Finland's relations with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) have undergone significant developments since the end of World War II. From maintaining a policy of neutrality during the Cold War to pursuing membership in the alliance, Finland's stance on NATO has evolved in response to changing regional and global security dynamics.

History
-------

### Background: Finnish neutrality at the end of World War II

Following the end of World War II, Finland adopted a policy of neutrality, seeking to maintain good relations with both the Western Bloc and the Eastern Bloc. The country's geographical location, bordering the Soviet Union, made it imperative to maintain a delicate balance between the two superpowers. The 1947 Paris Peace Treaty, which ended the state of war between Finland and the Allied Powers, cemented Finland's position as a neutral state.

### 1949â€“2023: Pre-membership relations

#### 1949â€“1991: Finnish neutrality during the Cold War

During the Cold War, Finland's neutral stance allowed it to maintain diplomatic relations with both the United States and the Soviet Union. The country participated in various international organizations, such as the United Nations, and engaged in trade with both Eastern and Western countries. Finland's military, however, remained non-aligned, and the country did not participate in any military alliances.

#### 1991â€“1995: Immediate aftermath of the Cold War

With the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, Finland began to reassess its foreign policy. The country joined the European Union (EU) in 1995, which marked a significant shift towards greater integration with Western Europe. Although Finland did not seek NATO membership at this time, it did participate in NATO's Partnership for Peace (PfP) program, which aimed to promote cooperation between NATO and non-member states.

#### 1995â€“2022: Shift from non-alignment within the European Union

Finland's participation in the EU led to increased cooperation with other member states on defense and security issues. The country contributed troops to EU-led peacekeeping missions and participated in the EU's Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). Although Finland maintained its non-alignment policy, the country's defense cooperation with NATO member states increased, and it participated in several NATO-led operations, including the International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) in Afghanistan.

#### 2022â€“2023: Accession process following the Russian invasion of Ukraine

##### February â€“ May 2022: Initial response to the invasion

In response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, Finland condemned the actions and provided humanitarian aid to Ukraine. The country also increased its military preparedness and participated in NATO's enhanced Forward Presence (eFP) in the Baltic region.

##### May â€“ June 2022: Declaration of intent, application

On May 15, 2022, Finland's President and Prime Minister jointly announced the country's intention to apply for NATO membership. The decision was supported by a majority of the Finnish Parliament. On May 18, 2022, Finland submitted its application to join NATO.

##### June 2022 â€“ April 2023: Ratification

Finland's accession process was rapid, with all 30 NATO member states approving the country's membership by April 2023. The ratification process was completed on April 4, 2023, when Turkey became the final country to approve Finland's membership.

### 2023â€“present: Finnish membership in NATO

Finland officially became the 31st member of NATO on April 4, 2023. The country's membership marks a significant shift in its foreign and security policy, as it transitions from a non-aligned state to a member of a military alliance. Finland's participation in NATO is expected to enhance the country's security and contribute to regional stability.

Finland's foreign relations with other NATO member states
---------------------------------------------------

Finland's membership in NATO has strengthened its relations with other member states. The country has increased its participation in NATO-led operations and has contributed to the alliance's efforts to enhance regional security. Finland's defense cooperation with other NATO member states, particularly with neighboring countries such as Estonia and Latvia, has also increased.

The Sandman (TV series)

The Sandman is a fantasy drama television series based on the comic book series of the same name by Neil Gaiman. The show premiered on Netflix on August 5, 2022, and has received widespread critical acclaim for its unique storytelling, atmospheric production design, and exceptional performances.

# Premise

The series follows the story of Dream, also known as Morpheus, one of the seven Endless, a family of powerful beings who personify various aspects of the universe. The story begins with Dream's capture by a mortal named Roderick Burgess, who seeks to gain ultimate power and control over the universe. After being held captive for 106 years, Dream manages to escape and sets out to reclaim his powers, kingdom, and family heirlooms.

As Dream navigates the complex world of dreams and reality, he must confront various characters from his past, including his siblings, who are determined to stop him from reclaiming his rightful place as the ruler of the Dreaming. Along the way, Dream encounters a range of characters, including humans, supernatural beings, and mythological creatures, who aid or hinder his progress.

# Production

## Development

### As a film

The Sandman was initially developed as a film, with various studios and producers attempting to adapt the comic book series for the big screen. However, the project faced numerous challenges, including the complexity of the story and the difficulty of translating the comic book's unique visual style to film.

### Transition to television

In 2019, Netflix announced that it had acquired the rights to adapt The Sandman as a television series. Neil Gaiman, who had been involved in various attempts to adapt the comic book series as a film, was brought on board as an executive producer, along with Allan Heinberg and David S. Goyer.

## Writing

The writing team for The Sandman included Neil Gaiman, Allan Heinberg, and David S. Goyer, who worked together to develop the show's overall story arc and episode scripts. The team drew heavily from the original comic book series, while also introducing new characters and storylines.

## Casting

The casting process for The Sandman involved a global search for actors who could bring the show's complex characters to life. Tom Sturridge was cast as Dream/Morpheus, while Boyd Holbrook was cast as the Corinthian. The rest of the cast was announced over the course of several months, with Patton Oswalt, Vivienne Acheampong, and Charles Dance joining the show in key roles.

## Production design

The production design team for The Sandman was led by Jon Gary Steele, who worked to create a unique and atmospheric visual style for the show. The team drew inspiration from the original comic book series, as well as various mythological and cultural references.

## Filming

Filming for The Sandman took place in the United Kingdom and Canada, with a team of experienced cinematographers and camera operators. The show's visual style was heavily influenced by the use of practical effects, with a focus on creating a dreamlike atmosphere.

## Post-production

The post-production process for The Sandman involved a team of editors, visual effects artists, and sound designers. The show's score was composed by David Buckley, who worked to create a unique and atmospheric soundtrack.

## Visual effects

The visual effects team for The Sandman was led by Clare Cheetham, who worked to create a range of complex and imaginative effects. The team used a combination of practical and CGI effects to bring the show's fantastical world to life.

# Music

# Release

The marketing campaign for The Sandman was led by Netflix, who worked to create a range of promotional materials, including trailers, posters, and social media content. The campaign focused on highlighting the show's unique visual style and complex characters.

# Reception

## Audience viewership

The Sandman premiered on Netflix on August 5, 2022, and was viewed by millions of people worldwide. The show's audience viewing figures were not publicly released, but it was reported that the show was one of the most-watched on Netflix during its premiere week.

## Critical response

The Sandman received widespread critical acclaim, with many reviewers praising the show's unique storytelling, atmospheric production design, and exceptional performances. The show holds a 92% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 8.1/10.

## Accolades

The Sandman received numerous awards and nominations, including several Primetime Emmy Awards. The show was also nominated for several other awards, including the Golden Globe Awards and the Screen Actors Guild Awards.

In November 2022, Netflix announced that it had ordered a spin-off series based on the Dead Boy Detectives, a pair of characters who appear in The Sandman. Killing of Ayman al-Zawahiri

Ayman al-Zawahiri, an Egyptian physician and militant Islamist, was killed in a drone strike conducted by the United States on July 31, 2022, in Kabul, Afghanistan. Al-Zawahiri had been the leader of the terrorist organization al-Qaeda since the death of Osama bin Laden in 2011. The operation marked a significant milestone in the global fight against terrorism and had far-reaching implications for international relations and security.

#Background

Ayman al-Zawahiri was born on June 19, 1951, in Maadi, Egypt. He earned a degree in medicine from Cairo University and later obtained a master's degree in surgery from the same institution. Al-Zawahiri's radicalization began in the 1970s, and he eventually became a key figure in the Egyptian Islamic Jihad (EIJ). In the 1980s, he met Osama bin Laden, and the two formed a close alliance that would last for decades.

Following the 9/11 attacks in 2001, al-Zawahiri became one of the most wanted men in the world. He survived numerous attempts on his life and continued to lead al-Qaeda, orchestrating various terrorist plots and attacks worldwide. Al-Zawahiri's leadership style was characterized by his intellectualism and strategic thinking, which allowed him to maintain a low profile while still influencing global events.

#Preparation

The operation to kill Ayman al-Zawahiri was the result of months of planning and intelligence gathering by the United States. The CIA, in cooperation with other intelligence agencies, had been tracking al-Zawahiri's movements and gathering information on his hideouts and security arrangements.

In 2020, the United States had withdrawn its troops from Afghanistan, but it continued to maintain a presence in the region through drone surveillance and special operations. Illegal Operation (Euphemism)

An illegal operation, also known as "the thing that had no name," is a euphemism used to refer to an abortion or other illicit medical procedures, particularly in the mid-20th century. The term was coined due to the sensitive and often illicit nature of these procedures, which were frequently performed in secret to avoid detection by law enforcement.

# History

## Background

In the early 20th century, abortion was a highly stigmatized and often illegal procedure in many countries. As a result, those seeking abortions, as well as the medical professionals performing them, were forced to operate in secret to avoid prosecution. This led to the development of a network of clandestine abortion providers, who often used coded language to communicate with clients and avoid detection.

## "The thing that had no name"

The term "illegal operation" emerged as a euphemism for abortion during this period. It was used to refer to the procedure without explicitly stating its nature, thereby avoiding detection by law enforcement or others who might be opposed to abortion. This euphemism was often used in conversation, as well as in print and other forms of communication.

## Abortion euphemism elsewhere in print

The use of euphemisms for abortion was not limited to the term "illegal operation." Other terms, such as "menstrual regulation" or "uterine evacuation," were also used to refer to abortion procedures. These euphemisms were often used in medical texts, as well as in popular literature and media.

# Law

The use of euphemisms for abortion was also reflected in the language used in laws and court decisions related to the procedure. In many jurisdictions, laws prohibiting abortion were written in a way that avoided explicitly mentioning the procedure. Instead, they might refer to "unlawful operations" or "unlawful procedures." This language was often used to avoid controversy and to maintain a level of plausible deniability.

# Art

The theme of "illegal operation" has been explored in various forms of art, including film, television, sculpture, and fiction.

## Film

Several films have addressed the theme of "illegal operation," often using the term as a euphemism for abortion. These films frequently explore the consequences of seeking an abortion in a society where the procedure is heavily stigmatized or illegal. Examples of films that have addressed this theme include "A Private Matter" (1992), which tells the story of a woman who seeks an abortion in the 1950s, and "Vera Drake" (2004), which explores the life of a woman who performs abortions in post-war Britain.

## Television

Television shows have also addressed the theme of "illegal operation," often using the term as a plot device to explore the consequences of seeking an abortion. Examples of television shows that have addressed this theme include "Mad Men" (2007-2015), which features a character who seeks an abortion in the 1960s, and "Call the Midwife" (2012-present), which explores the lives of midwives in post-war Britain, including their experiences with abortion.

## Sculpture

The theme of "illegal operation" has also been explored in sculpture, often using the term as a metaphor for the secrecy and shame surrounding abortion. Examples of sculptures that have addressed this theme include "The Abortion Project" by artist Joyce Wieland, which features a series of sculptures that explore the experience of seeking an abortion.

## Fiction

The theme of "illegal operation" has been explored in various works of fiction, often using the term as a metaphor for the secrecy and shame surrounding abortion. Examples of works of fiction that have addressed this theme include "The Bell Jar" by Sylvia Plath (1963), which features a character who seeks an abortion, and "The Handmaid's Tale" by Margaret Atwood (1985), which explores a dystopian society where abortion is heavily restricted.

In conclusion, the term "illegal operation" has been used as a euphemism for abortion, particularly in the mid-20th century. The term has been used in various forms of art, including film, television, sculpture, and fiction, often to explore the consequences of seeking an abortion in a society where the procedure is heavily stigmatized or illegal.

================

The Gujarat Titans are a professional Twenty20 cricket team based in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India. They are a part of the Indian Premier League (IPL) and made their debut in the 2022 season. The team is owned by CVC Capital Partners, a British private equity firm.

Franchise History
----------------

The Gujarat Titans franchise was established in 2021 as one of two new teams added to the Indian Premier League, along with the Lucknow Super Giants. The team was sold to CVC Capital Partners for a record-breaking â‚¹5,625 crore (US$720 million), the highest price paid for an IPL franchise at the time. They defeated the Royal Challengers Bangalore in the Eliminator match, but lost to the Rajasthan Royals in the Qualifier 1 match.

The team's mascot is a lion named "Aahvaan", which is a Gujarati word for "call to action".

Kirstie Alley

Kirstie Alley is an American actress, comedian, and spokesmodel who has appeared in numerous films and television shows throughout her career. Born on January 12, 1951, in Wichita, Kansas, Alley rose to prominence in the 1980s with her breakout role as Rebecca Howe on the NBC sitcom "Cheers." Known for her distinctive voice, sharp wit, and charismatic on-screen presence, Alley has established herself as a beloved and enduring figure in American entertainment.

#Early life and education

Kirstie Alley was born to Robert Deal Alley and Lillian Alley (nÃ©e Mickelson) in Wichita, Kansas. Her father was a lumber company owner, and her mother was a homemaker. Alley has two siblings, Craig and Colette. She grew up in a close-knit family and was raised in a conservative household.

Alley attended Wichita Southeast High School and later enrolled at Kansas State University, where she studied drama and speech. However, she left college after her sophomore year to pursue a career in modeling. Alley moved to Los Angeles in 1979 to pursue a career in acting and comedy.

#Career

Alley's early career in Hollywood was marked by small roles in films and television shows. She made her film debut in 1982 with a minor role in the comedy film "Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan." She continued to work in film and television throughout the 1980s, appearing in shows such as "The Love Boat" and "Magnum P.I."

Alley's breakthrough role came in 1987 when she was cast as Rebecca Howe on the NBC sitcom "Cheers." The show was a critical and commercial success, and Alley's performance earned her numerous award nominations, including a Golden Globe and an Emmy. She remained on the show for six seasons, becoming a household name and establishing herself as a talented comedic actress.

In the 1990s, Alley appeared in a number of films, including "Look Who's Talking" (1989), "Look Who's Talking Too" (1990), and "Look Who's Talking Now" (1993). She also starred in the television series "Veronica's Closet" from 1997 to 2000.

In the 2000s, Alley continued to work in film and television, appearing in shows such as "Fat Actress" and "Kirstie Alley's Big Life." She also competed on the reality TV show "Dancing with the Stars" in 2011.
